answer_html: Reality check: Note that we obtain the same value for \(V_2\) with both methods. To visualize the full bowl we can look at the 3D figure .

hints_html:
Draw a picture. Visualize the two ways of integrating as referred to in the hint.

Write down two integrals that represent the volume \(V_2\) of the solid. Which one would you prefer to evaluate?

In this case, both integrals are possible to evaluate using the techniques that you’ve learned. It is a good reality check (and also a good exercise) to compute both integrals and ensure that you obtain the same result.

hints_raw:
Draw a picture.  Visualize the two ways of integrating as referred to in the hint.
Write down two integrals that represent the volume <math> V_2</math> of the solid.  Which one would you prefer to evaluate?
In this case, both integrals are possible to evaluate using the techniques that you've learned.  It is a good reality check (and also a good exercise) to compute both integrals and ensure that you obtain the same result.
question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
Disc Method. In this solution, we consider the volume as a sum of slices, cut orthogonal to the \(y\)-axis. Each slice has volume \(\pi r^2 \Delta y\), where \(r\) is its radius and \(\Delta y\) is its thickness. The bowl will be made by rotating the shaded blue region in the 2D figure . If the slice is at height \(y\), then its radius is equal to \(x\), where \(y=e^x\). Hence, \(r=\ln y.\) In the limit \(\Delta y\to 0,\)

\[\begin{aligned} V_2= \int_1^e \pi (\ln y)^2 \, dy\end{aligned}\]

Note that the limits of integration are \(f(0)=e^0=1\) and \(f(1)=e^1=e,\) since \(x\) ranges from 0 to 1.

We use integration by parts to evaluate this integral, letting \(f(y)=g(y)=\ln y.\) So in order to perform the integration by parts we need to recall the antiderivative of \(\ln y\). To calculate this antiderivative we again use integration by parts:

\[\begin{aligned} \int \ln y dy &= \int 1\cdot \ln y\, dy = y\ln y - \int y \cdot \frac{1}{y} \, dy \\ &= y\ln y - \int 1 \, dy= y\ln y - y +C.\end{aligned}\]

We now use this antiderivative to perform the integration by parts in the integral for \(V_2.\) Hence,

\[\begin{aligned} V_2&=\pi \int_1^e (\ln y)^2 \, dy \\ &= \pi \left[ \ln y (y\ln y - y)\right]_1^e - \pi\int _1^e \frac{1}{y}(y\ln y - y) \, dy\\ &= \pi \left[ 1 (e\cdot 1 - e) - 0\right] - \pi\int _1^e (\ln y - 1) \, dy\\ &= - \pi\left[y\ln y-y - y\right]_1^e \\ &= - \pi\left[e\ln e-e-e - 1\ln 1+1+1\right] \\ &= - \pi\left( - e +2\right) \\ &= \pi\left( e-2 \right). \end{aligned}\]

Reality check: Note that we obtain the same value for \(V_2\) with both methods. To visualize the full bowl we can look at the 3D figure .

Shell method. In this solution, we consider the solid to be a sum of cylindrical shells. Each cylindrical shell has volume \(2\pi r(x) h(x) \Delta r,\) where \(r(x)\) is its radius, \(h(x)\) is its height and \(\Delta r\) is its thickness. The bowl will be made up by rotating the blue shaded region in the 2D figure . From there we have \(r(x)=x\), \(h(x)=f(1)-f(x) = e-e^x,\) and \(\Delta r =\Delta x\). In the limit \(\Delta x \to 0,\) we obtain the volume by integrating along the x-axis:

\[\begin{aligned} V_2 &= \int_0^1 2\pi r(x)h(x) \, dx \\ &= \int_0^1 2\pi x (e-e^x) \, dx\\ &= 2\pi e \int_0^1 x\, dx -2\pi \int_0^1 x e^x \, dx\\ &= 2\pi e \left[\frac{x^2}{2}\right]_0^1 -2\pi \left(\left[x e^x\right]_0^1-\int_0^1 e^x \, dx\right)\\ &= 2\pi e \frac{1}{2} -2\pi \left( e- \left[e^x\right]_0^1 \right)\\ &= \pi e -2\pi \left( e- (e-1) \right)\\ &= \pi e -2\pi \\ &= \pi (e -2).\end{aligned}\]

(We used integration by parts in the second integral to get from the third to the fourth line.)

Reality check: Note that we obtain the same value for \(V_2\) with both methods. To visualize the full bowl we can look at the 3D figure .
sols_latex:
\textbf{Disc Method.} In this solution, we consider the volume as a sum
of slices, cut orthogonal to the $y$-axis. Each slice has volume
$\pi r^2 \Delta y$, where $r$ is its radius and $\Delta y$ is its
thickness. The bowl will be made by rotating the shaded blue region in
the 2D figure \includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH103/April_2011/Math103Apr11Q4b-2dgraph.png}. If the
slice is at height $y$, then its radius is equal to $x$, where $y=e^x$.
Hence, $r=\ln y.$ In the limit $\Delta y\to 0,$

\begin{align*}
V_2= \int_1^e \pi (\ln y)^2 \, dy
\end{align*}

Note that the limits of integration are $f(0)=e^0=1$ and $f(1)=e^1=e,$
since $x$ ranges from 0 to 1.

We use integration by parts to evaluate this integral, letting
$f(y)=g(y)=\ln y.$ So in order to perform the integration by parts we
need to recall the antiderivative of $\ln y$. To calculate this
antiderivative we again use integration by parts:

\begin{align*}
\int \ln y dy &= \int 1\cdot \ln y\, dy = y\ln y - \int y \cdot \frac{1}{y} \, dy \\
&= y\ln y -  \int 1 \, dy= y\ln y -  y +C.
\end{align*}

We now use this antiderivative to perform the integration by parts in
the integral for $V_2.$ Hence,

\begin{align*}
V_2&=\pi \int_1^e  (\ln y)^2 \, dy \\
&= \pi \left[ \ln y (y\ln y -  y)\right]_1^e - \pi\int _1^e \frac{1}{y}(y\ln y -  y) \, dy\\
&= \pi \left[ 1 (e\cdot 1 -  e) - 0\right] - \pi\int _1^e (\ln y -  1) \, dy\\
&= - \pi\left[y\ln y-y -  y\right]_1^e \\
&= - \pi\left[e\ln e-e-e - 1\ln 1+1+1\right] \\
&= - \pi\left( - e +2\right) \\
&= \pi\left(  e-2 \right). 
\end{align*}

\emph{Reality check:} Note that we obtain the same value for $V_2$ with
both methods. To visualize the full bowl we can look at the 3D figure
\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH103/April_2011/Math103Apr11Q4b-3dgraph.png}.

\textbf{Shell method.} In this solution, we consider the solid to be a
sum of cylindrical shells. Each cylindrical shell has volume
$2\pi r(x) h(x) \Delta r,$ where $r(x)$ is its radius, $h(x)$ is its
height and $\Delta r$ is its thickness. The bowl will be made up by
rotating the blue shaded region in the 2D figure
\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH103/April_2011/Math103Apr11Q4b-2dgraph.png}. From there we have
$r(x)=x$, $h(x)=f(1)-f(x) = e-e^x,$ and $\Delta r =\Delta x$. In the
limit $\Delta x \to 0,$ we obtain the volume by integrating along the
\emph{x}-axis:

\begin{align*}
V_2 &= \int_0^1 2\pi r(x)h(x) \, dx \\
&= \int_0^1 2\pi x (e-e^x) \, dx\\
&= 2\pi e \int_0^1  x\, dx -2\pi \int_0^1 x e^x \, dx\\
&= 2\pi  e \left[\frac{x^2}{2}\right]_0^1 -2\pi \left(\left[x e^x\right]_0^1-\int_0^1 e^x \, dx\right)\\
&= 2\pi  e \frac{1}{2} -2\pi \left( e- \left[e^x\right]_0^1 \right)\\
&= \pi  e  -2\pi \left( e- (e-1) \right)\\
&= \pi  e  -2\pi \\
&= \pi  (e  -2).
\end{align*}

(We used integration by parts in the second integral to get from the
third to the fourth line.)

\emph{Reality check:} Note that we obtain the same value for $V_2$ with
both methods. To visualize the full bowl we can look at the 3D figure
\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH103/April_2011/Math103Apr11Q4b-3dgraph.png}.
sols_raw:
'''Disc Method.''' In this solution, we consider the volume as a sum of slices, cut orthogonal to the <math>y </math>-axis.  Each slice has volume <math>\pi r^2 \Delta y </math>, where <math> r</math> is its radius and <math>\Delta y </math> is its thickness.  The bowl will be made by rotating the shaded blue region in the 2D figure [[File:Math103Apr11Q4b-2dgraph.png|thumbnail|500px|xy 2D image]].  If the slice is at height <math>y </math>, then its radius is equal to <math> x</math>, where <math> y=e^x</math>.  Hence, <math>r=\ln y. </math>  In the limit <math>\Delta y\to 0, </math>

:<math> \begin{align}
V_2= \int_1^e \pi (\ln y)^2 \, dy
\end{align}</math>

Note that the limits of integration are <math> f(0)=e^0=1</math>  and <math> f(1)=e^1=e,</math> since <math>  x</math> ranges from 0 to 1.

We use integration by parts to evaluate this integral, letting <math> f(y)=g(y)=\ln y.</math> So in order to perform the integration by parts we need to recall the antiderivative of <math>\ln y</math>. To calculate this antiderivative we again use integration by parts:

:<math> \begin{align}
\int \ln y dy &= \int 1\cdot \ln y\, dy = y\ln y - \int y \cdot \frac{1}{y} \, dy \\
&= y\ln y -  \int 1 \, dy= y\ln y -  y +C.
\end{align}</math>

We now use this antiderivative to perform the integration by parts in the integral for <math>V_2.</math> Hence, 

:<math> \begin{align}
V_2&=\pi \int_1^e  (\ln y)^2 \, dy \\
&= \pi \left[ \ln y (y\ln y -  y)\right]_1^e - \pi\int _1^e \frac{1}{y}(y\ln y -  y) \, dy\\
&= \pi \left[ 1 (e\cdot 1 -  e) - 0\right] - \pi\int _1^e (\ln y -  1) \, dy\\
&= - \pi\left[y\ln y-y -  y\right]_1^e \\
&= - \pi\left[e\ln e-e-e - 1\ln 1+1+1\right] \\
&= - \pi\left( - e +2\right) \\
&= \pi\left(  e-2 \right). \\
\end{align}</math>

''Reality check:''  Note that we obtain the same value for <math> V_2</math> with both methods.  To visualize the full bowl we can look at the 3D figure [[File:Math103Apr11Q4b-3dgraph.png|thumbnail|500px|Full 3D image from rotation]].
'''Shell method.''' In this solution, we consider the solid to be a sum of cylindrical shells.  Each cylindrical shell has volume <math> 2\pi r(x) h(x) \Delta r,</math> where <math>r(x) </math> is its radius, <math>h(x) </math> is its height and <math>\Delta r </math> is its thickness.  The bowl will be made up by rotating the blue shaded region in the 2D figure [[File:Math103Apr11Q4b-2dgraph.png|thumbnail|500px|xy 2D image]].  From there we have <math>r(x)=x </math>, <math>h(x)=f(1)-f(x) = e-e^x, </math> and <math>\Delta r =\Delta x</math>. In the limit <math>\Delta x \to 0,</math> we obtain the volume by integrating along the ''x''-axis:

<math> \begin{align}
V_2 &= \int_0^1 2\pi r(x)h(x) \, dx \\
&= \int_0^1 2\pi x (e-e^x) \, dx\\
&= 2\pi e \int_0^1  x\, dx -2\pi \int_0^1 x e^x \, dx\\
&= 2\pi  e \left[\frac{x^2}{2}\right]_0^1 -2\pi \left(\left[x e^x\right]_0^1-\int_0^1 e^x \, dx\right)\\
&= 2\pi  e \frac{1}{2} -2\pi \left( e- \left[e^x\right]_0^1 \right)\\
&= \pi  e  -2\pi \left( e- (e-1) \right)\\
&= \pi  e  -2\pi \\
&= \pi  (e  -2).
\end{align}</math>

(We used integration by parts in the second integral to get from the third to the fourth line.)

''Reality check:''  Note that we obtain the same value for <math> V_2</math> with both methods.  To visualize the full bowl we can look at the 3D figure [[File:Math103Apr11Q4b-3dgraph.png|thumbnail|500px|Full 3D image from rotation]].
statement_html:
Consider the function \(f(x)=e^x\) for 0 \(\leq\) x \(\leq\) 1.

Find the volume \(V_2\) of the bowl when rotating \(f(x)\) around the \(y\)-axis. (Note: for this problem there are two ways to set the relevant integral up - either one is fine. One way involves rewriting \(f(x)\) as \(x=g(y)\).)
statement_latex:
Consider the function $f(x)=e^x$ for 0 $\leq$ x $\leq$ 1.

Find the volume $V_2$ of the bowl when rotating $f(x)$ around the
$y$-axis. (Note: for this problem there are two ways to set the relevant
integral up - either one is fine. One way involves rewriting $f(x)$ as
$x=g(y)$.)
statement_raw:
Consider the function <math>f(x)=e^x</math> for 0 ≤ x ≤ 1.

Find the volume <math>V_2</math> of the bowl when rotating <math>f(x)</math> around the <math>y</math>-axis. (Note: for this problem there are two ways to set the relevant integral up - either one is fine. One way involves rewriting <math>f(x)</math> as <math>x=g(y)</math>.)
